items.title: 400 bad request with nginx / gunicorn
debugsqlshell no longer showing sql after upgrade
items.body:
[requirements-django-3.0.txt](https://github.com/jazzband/django-debug-toolbar/files/4055733/requirements-django-3.0.txt)
[requirements-before-django-3.0.txt](https://github.com/jazzband/django-debug-toolbar/files/4055734/requirements-before-django-3.0.txt)

We are using postgres 12 and python 3.8.   

A couple of days ago we updated to Django 3.0 from 2.2.6 and we just noticed that the debugsqlshell is no longer showing us the SQL used for db queries.

The attached files show the before and after of the library upgrade we performed.

Note that
- We aren't seeing any error messages in the shell.   It is just the case that the SQL isn't displaying
- The debug toolbar _does_ show the SQL for db queries
- If we switch from postgres to sqlite, debugsqlshell _does_ show the SQL
   ( This isn't something we can rely on because a significant amount of our code relies on postgres specific features )
- I have attempted to just downgrade psycopg2 however it seems there is some sort of psycopg2 bug that prevents the downgrade from succeeding.

Any help would be appreciated.

items.title: The toolbar isn’t displaying when using gzip.
items.body: We had to look hard to find why the toolbar was showing on some views but not on others. After a lot of effort we realized it was becouse of gzip. In the documentation's Tips part you can add this to reasons why toolbar wouldn't show up. It can make it a lot easier for some people.

items.title: Current 2.1 version doesn't support Django 1.11

In the docs it's been said "The current stable version of the Debug Toolbar is 2.1. It works on Django ≥ 1.11." which means it should support 1.11 but it doesn't. simply because the MIDDLEWARE in settings file is written like MIDDLEWARE_CLASSES by the old style. in the debug_toolbar/apps.py line 25 the codes it's using MIDDLEWARE

Would this be considered?

items.title: Server-Timing header formatted incorrectly?
items.body:
The `Server-Timing` response header which was added in #928 exposes a lot of valuable information, but it looks like it's not formatted according to [the latest version of the W3C spec](https://www.w3.org/TR/server-timing/).

A demonstration of the problem can be seen in Chrome's dev tools. `Server-Timings` should be parsed and displayed here, but it's not quite working. Here's the header which is being sent (with added whitespace for readability):

```
Server-Timing: TimerPanel_utime=64.00000000000006; "User CPU time",
    TimerPanel_stime=16.000000000000014; "System CPU time",
    TimerPanel_total=80.00000000000007; "Total CPU time",
    TimerPanel_total_time=80.66487312316895; "Elapsed time",
    SQLPanel_sql_time=1.6126632690429688; "SQL 1 queries",
    CachePanel_total_time=0; "Cache 0 Calls"
```

…and here's how Chrome shows this:

![Screenshot 2019-11-15 at 11 29 13](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/76330/68940629-9f2be200-079b-11ea-9fcd-094d290a668a.png)

I think the header should be something like this:

```
Server-Timing: TimerPanel_utime;dur=64.00000000000006;desc="User CPU time",
    TimerPanel_stime;dur=16.000000000000014;desc="System CPU time",
    TimerPanel_total;dur=80.00000000000007;desc="Total CPU time",
    TimerPanel_total_time;dur=80.66487312316895;desc="Elapsed time",
    SQLPanel_sql_time;dur=1.6126632690429688;desc="SQL 1 queries",
    CachePanel_total_time;dur=0;desc="Cache 0 Calls"
```

items.title: Missing toolbar when using DRF PATCH form
items.body:
DRF auto html views + debug-toolbar is a great combo to debug sql performance for GET requests.
However, when doing PATCH requests (using the same DRF auto html view: raw form) the toolbar disappears, and I cannot analyze sql queries.

It would be great to be able to analyze sql queries with DRF PATCH forms too.

items.title: The panel API is not included in the rendered documentation
items.body:
The source for the `panels.html` documentation page includes a section for the `Panel` API (https://github.com/jazzband/django-debug-toolbar/blame/5299cf826284b6e082c5f18050e4f706faa81c39/docs/panels.rst#L307).  I remember referencing this API in a previous version of the documentation, but in the current version of the documentation at Read the Docs it is blank:  https://django-debug-toolbar.readthedocs.io/en/stable/panels.html#api-for-third-party-panels.

Looking at the logs for the latest document build on Read the Docs (https://readthedocs.org/projects/django-debug-toolbar/builds/9803859/), I noticed the following warning:

```
WARNING: autodoc: failed to import class u'panels.Panel' from module u'debug_toolbar'; the following exception was raised:
cannot import name lru_cache
```

From looking elsewhere in the logs, it appears that Read the Docs is using Python 2.7 to build the docs, while `lru_cache` was added in Python 3.2.  The fix is probably just to update Read the Docs to use Python 3, but as there is no `readthedocs.yml` file in the repo, I think this change will have to be made using the Read the Docs admin panel.

Where can be the problem or how can we debug it ?

items.title: Ability to run in production environment via url param/cookie
items.body:
I apologize in advance if this has already been requested.

Troubleshooting an issue in production (especially SQL) could be made easier if there was a way to pass in a url param and/or cookie to display the debug toolbar. This would be more of an override flag to the `DEBUG` flag in `settings.py`.

items.title: Incompatibility of django-toolbar 1.8 and django-extensions 2.2.1 caused by get_version method
items.body:
Django-toolbar version : 1.8
Django-extensions version : 2.2.1

When using this 2 apps in conjunction, it breaks with message : `TypeError at / get_version() missing 1 required positional argument: 'version'`

Indeed django-toolbar uses the `get_version` attribute of django-extensions ([ref code](https://github.com/jazzband/django-debug-toolbar/blob/1.8/debug_toolbar/panels/versions.py#L43)) but this function expects an positional argument ([ref code](https://github.com/django-extensions/django-extensions/blob/4dcf2a9a2c2c03182c957aa5a56fca1cc8d9ec1f/django_extensions/__init__.py#L5))

A potential fix could be to wrap the call to `app.get_version` in a try..catch block but I am not sure it is the nicest way to go.

Many thanks for the great work on djtoolbar,

items.title: Docs have incorrect default for HIDE_IN_STACKTRACES
items.body:
At https://django-debug-toolbar.readthedocs.io/en/latest/configuration.html , the `HIDE_IN_STACKTRACES` default is stated to be `('socketserver', 'threading', 'wsgiref', 'debug_toolbar', 'django')`. The actual default only hides a few Django modules, not all of it.

In 2.0, the actual default is:
```
    "HIDE_IN_STACKTRACES": (
        "socketserver",
        "threading",
        "wsgiref",
        "debug_toolbar",
        "django.db",
        "django.core.handlers",
        "django.core.servers",
        "django.utils.decorators",
        "django.utils.deprecation",
        "django.utils.functional",
    ),
```

Edit: I just realized that these are prefixes rather than exact matches, so submodules are also omitted, which is great. Would this be worth documenting?

Related question: Is anyone else having their browser lag and max out a CPU core when looking at the SQL panel with stacktraces enabled? The reason I noticed this doc issue was I wanted to add django.test.utils, django.template.base, and django.template.loader_tags to the hidden modules to see if that fixed my issue. (I get a lot of those in certain SQL stacktraces.)

items.title: Django 1.11 support should be removed from the docs
items.body:
I've been trying this for a while now, as when upgrading the toolbar to the latest version (currently 2.0) starts giving `Not found` errors (see image below).

After reviewing that both the README and setup.py state that it's supporting Django 1.11, then I found that after toolbar 1.10 support for Django 1.11 was dropped: https://django-debug-toolbar.readthedocs.io/en/latest/changes.html#id4

Downgrading to `django-debug-toolbar<1.10` fixes the toolbar for Django 1.11 as expected.

Please amend the README and setup.py to reflect the actual Django versions supported.

Thanks!

![not-found](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3706329/60967420-8786ad80-a312-11e9-9654-05f75793d128.png)

items.title: Read the docs outdated
items.body:
I was looking for changes in the recent 2.0 release and found a changelog in the documentation. However, it's missing the recent updates. Looking at the build history, RTD hasn't received webhooks in the past 6 months:

https://readthedocs.org/projects/django-debug-toolbar/builds/

I've had the same problem on other projects of mine and it's most likely due to a recent deprecations in their webhook:

https://blog.readthedocs.com/webhook-deprecations/

The fix is to get the new Webhook URL in the RTD [admin panel for integrations](https://readthedocs.org/dashboard/django-debug-toolbar/integrations/) and then add it in the [webhook section on Github](https://github.com/jazzband/django-debug-toolbar/settings/hooks).

items.title: IndexError: list index out of range - when a repr renders templates
items.body:
Related to: https://github.com/wagtail/wagtail/issues/5243

The `__repr__` method on an object in template context rendered a form, instead of just a simple string. Newer versions of Django have forms with widgets which render templates in them.

For some reason, with Postgres, a ModelChoiceIterator on a form, with a repr method which starts rendering templates, calling `pformat` on those variables in template context immediately evaluates them.

I've got a test case for it, which will be in the PR which hopefully fixes it.

items.title: Allow impersonation of user accounts
items.body:
A lot of times, what a user sees, or even what different users see, can be vastly different. And while there's value in ensuring that your log-in/log-out functionality works when swapping users in your dev environment, it seems like it could be a useful feature for DDT to allow for a 'quick-swapper' between existing users, so you can quickly swap through the current page and make sure it behaves as expected for your users as you're creating it.

Thoughts?

items.title: sql_select, sql_explain fails with json contains queries
items.body:
Consider this simple query (data is a `JSONField`):

```
ApiUser.objects.filter(data__contains={"is_member": True})

The sql panel will show this query correctly:

```
SELECT ... FROM "api_apiuser" WHERE "api_apiuser"."data" @> '{"is_member": true}' LIMIT 21

2019-01-23 16:13:40,664 DEBUG: utils.py:111: (0.003) SELECT ... FROM "api_apiuser" WHERE "api_apiuser"."data" @> '''{"is_member": true}'''  LIMIT 21; args=['\'{"is_member": true}\'']

`cursor.execute()` fails because of the triple quotation marks(?).

items.title: Logging not being captured on Django Admin Page
items.body:
It seems that the logging panel isn't capturing log records when I'm on the Admin panel.
I can get it to work everywhere but on Django Admin pages.

**Steps to reproduce**
1- Override save() method of a model to 
```
import logging
logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)
...
class Foo(models.Model):
    def save(self,*args,**kwargs):
        super().save(*args, **kwargs)
        logger.error("log message")
        print("If this shows up in console we now that method is being called")
```
Logging settings in settings.py
```
LOGGING = {
    'version': 1,
    'disable_existing_loggers': False,
    'incremental': True,
    'root': {
        'level': 'DEBUG',
    },
}
```
2- Go to Django admin and update a model instance to trigger save(). Notice lack of logging message in DDT logging panel, but "If this shows up in console we now that method is being called" showing up in console.
3- Remove DDT from Django project
4- Go to Django Admin and trigger save()
5- Notice log message show up in console

items.title: Detecting duplicate queries breaks for non-hashable query params
items.body:
Since commit 844353e4cb9855d76e4fa8b0f48de140d2588204, SQL query params are used to detect duplicate queries. A `duplicate_key` is created and then used as a key to a dict:

https://github.com/jazzband/django-debug-toolbar/blob/05ffccfb68fac64eeba9894707f9b6771e462648/debug_toolbar/panels/sql/panel.py#L151-L153

https://github.com/jazzband/django-debug-toolbar/blob/844353e4cb9855d76e4fa8b0f48de140d2588204/debug_toolbar/panels/sql/panel.py#L177

https://github.com/jazzband/django-debug-toolbar/blob/844353e4cb9855d76e4fa8b0f48de140d2588204/debug_toolbar/panels/sql/panel.py#L248

---

This fails when `raw_params` contains non-hashable items like lists. I saw it happen for the following query using a Postgres [`ArrayField`][], ~~but it should also be triggered by a simple `.filter(pk__in=[1, 2, 3])`~~:

```python
cls.objects.filter(
            Q(to_emails__contains=[customer.email]) |
            Q(cc_emails__contains=[customer.email]) |
            Q(bcc_emails__contains=[customer.email])
        )
```

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/.../lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/core/handlers/exception.py", line 35, in inner
    response = get_response(request)
  File "/.../lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/utils/deprecation.py", line 97, in __call__
    response = self.process_response(request, response)
  File "/.../lib/python3.6/site-packages/debug_toolbar/middleware.py", line 126, in process_response
    panel.generate_stats(request, response)
  File "/.../lib/python3.6/site-packages/debug_toolbar/panels/sql/panel.py", line 178, in generate_stats
    query_duplicates[alias][duplicate_key(query)] += 1
TypeError: unhashable type: 'list'
```

*(Edit: passing lists to `__in` works fine.)*

[`ArrayField`]: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.1/ref/contrib/postgres/fields/#arrayfield

items.title: Wrong IP when multiple networks in Docker
items.body:
The solution used in [cookiecutter-django](https://github.com/pydanny/cookiecutter-django) does not work when the Django container is connected to multiple networks in Docker. The solution is something like the following (taken from this [SO post](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/26898597/django-debug-toolbar-and-docker/45624773)): 

```python
import socket

ip = socket.gethostbyname(socket.gethostname())
INTERNAL_IPS = ['127.0.0.1', ip[:-1] + '1']
```

My Docker Compose configuration has the following items:

```yaml
networks:
  web_network: {}
  cache_network: {}
  database_network: {}


services:
  djangoapp:
    networks:
      - database_network
      - web_network
      - cache_network
```

Now the IP returned by `ip = socket.gethostbyname(socket.gethostname())` is not always the same. It seems to be the IP of one of the different available networks (if that makes sense). So sometimes it works, but most of the time it does not. 

I ended up adding all the possible IPs based on the one returned by `socket`, something like:
```python
def internal_docker_ips(base_ip):
    numbers = base_ip.split('.')
    return [
        '.'.join([numbers[0], str(i), numbers[2], str(j)])
        for i in range(1, 254) for j in (1, 3)  # all IPs ending with '.1' and '.3'
    ]

INTERNAL_IPS = [
    '127.0.0.1',
]

INTERNAL_IPS.extend(
    internal_docker_ips(
        socket.gethostbyname(
            socket.gethostname())))

# ['127.0.0.1', '172.1.0.1', '172.1.0.3', '172.2.0.1', '172.2.0.3', ..., '172.253.0.1', '172.253.0.3']
```

Is there a cleaner workaround for this? Did any of you have the same issue? It might not be related to Django Debug Toolbar itself but any help is appreciated and will I believe be useful for others.

items.title: Missing SQL queries
items.body:
While recently trying to diagnose a slow admin page, I noticed that certain queries were missing from the SQL panel. By looking at the `django.db.backends` log I can see that the missing queries are exactly those that are using named cursors (`DECLARE ... NO SCROLL CURSOR WITH HOLD FOR SELECT `) instead of regular `SELECT` statements. I believe that these are server-side cursors used with PostgreSQL for code that uses `queryset.iterator()` (such as [`ModelChoiceField`](https://github.com/django/django/blob/a38ae914d89809aed6d79337b74a8b31b6d3849a/django/forms/models.py#L1136)).

So my guess is that DJDT is not recording queries that use these cursors, but I'm not sure.

I'm using DJDT version 1.9.1 and Django 2.0.1.

items.title: Using Django Debug Toolbar in djangoproject.com
items.body:
I'm working on [djangoproject.com](https://github.com/django/djangoproject.com) website with Django Debug Toolbar configured in this [dev settings](https://github.com/django/djangoproject.com/blob/master/djangoproject/settings/dev.py).

I found an issue with django debug toolbar that I reported in this issue [#796](https://github.com/django/djangoproject.com/issues/796) of djanoproject.com but I think it's a bug, as I reported.

Django Debug Toolbar works well for `www` , for example, if I open http://www.djangoproject.dev:8000/ I can show the toolbar and open the SQL panel.

If I try to open for example http://docs.djangoproject.dev:8000/en/1.11/ I can see the toolbar but I got `0: error` if I try to open SQL panel

This is the message I saw on browser console:
`Failed to load http://www.djangoproject.dev:8000/__debug__/render_panel/?store_id=212b2bb5adc54a3a81b97b6da5547d4c&panel_id=SQLPanel: No 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' header is present on the requested resource. Origin 'http://docs.djangoproject.dev:8000' is therefore not allowed access.`

If i open the url http://www.djangoproject.dev:8000/__debug__/render_panel/?store_id=212b2bb5adc54a3a81b97b6da5547d4c&panel_id=SQLPanel I can see all the data

I think the problem is the toolbar is trying to open a www. for the panel instead of a doc. url but I don't know how to update the settings to fix this.

items.title: Intercept redirects will cause ContentNotRenderedError with django-debug-toolbar 1.9
items.body:
I tried newest django-debug-toolbar, 1.9.
And when I enabled Intercept Redirects and accessed a view returns 302, It returned `ContentNotRenderedError`:

```
ContentNotRenderedError at /admin/

The response content must be rendered before it can be accessed.

Request Method: 	GET
Request URL: 	http://127.0.0.1:8000/admin/
Django Version: 	1.11.7
Exception Type: 	ContentNotRenderedError
Exception Value: 	

The response content must be rendered before it can be accessed.

Exception Location: 	/tmp/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/template/response.py in content, line 129
Python Executable: 	/tmp/venv/bin/python
Python Version: 	3.6.3
Python Path: 	

['/tmp/myproj',
 '/usr/lib/python36.zip',
 '/usr/lib/python3.6',
 '/usr/lib/python3.6/lib-dynload',
 '/tmp/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages']

Server time: 	Wed, 15 Nov 2017 11:17:34 +0000

Environment:


Request Method: GET
Request URL: http://127.0.0.1:8000/admin/

Django Version: 1.11.7
Python Version: 3.6.3
Installed Applications:
['django.contrib.admin',
 'django.contrib.auth',
 'django.contrib.contenttypes',
 'django.contrib.sessions',
 'django.contrib.messages',
 'django.contrib.staticfiles',
 'debug_toolbar']
Installed Middleware:
['debug_toolbar.middleware.DebugToolbarMiddleware',
 'django.middleware.security.SecurityMiddleware',
 'django.contrib.sessions.middleware.SessionMiddleware',
 'django.middleware.common.CommonMiddleware',
 'django.middleware.csrf.CsrfViewMiddleware',
 'django.contrib.auth.middleware.AuthenticationMiddleware',
 'django.contrib.messages.middleware.MessageMiddleware',
 'django.middleware.clickjacking.XFrameOptionsMiddleware']



Traceback:

File "/tmp/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/core/handlers/exception.py" in inner
  41.             response = get_response(request)

File "/tmp/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/utils/deprecation.py" in __call__
  142.             response = self.process_response(request, response)

File "/tmp/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/debug_toolbar/middleware.py" in process_response
  125.         content = force_text(response.content, encoding=response.charset)

File "/tmp/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/django/template/response.py" in content
  129.                 'The response content must be rendered before it can be accessed.'

Exception Type: ContentNotRenderedError at /admin/
Exception Value: The response content must be rendered before it can be accessed.
```

## Reason

This error caused by `content = force_text(response.content, encoding=response.charset)`, accessing `response.content`.

In this case the `response` was returned by `RedirectsPanel`.
https://github.com/jazzband/django-debug-toolbar/blob/master/debug_toolbar/panels/redirects.py#L9

The panel returns `SimpleTemplateResponse` object. this class will raise `ContentNotRenderedError` when `response.content` was accessed before calling `response.render()`.
like `content = force_text(response.content, ...)`.

This error wasn't on django-debug-toolbar 1.8.
And I think this change caused it
https://github.com/jazzband/django-debug-toolbar/commit/c369384945cfc5a4e65fa5f153e231a7ec06b11b

## Fix idea

Simply, we can avoid this error by adding `response.render()` in `RedirectsPanel`,
folloing here https://github.com/jazzband/django-debug-toolbar/blob/master/debug_toolbar/panels/redirects.py#L27

like this.

```python
                # Using SimpleTemplateResponse avoids running global context processors.
                response = SimpleTemplateResponse('debug_toolbar/redirect.html', context)
                response.cookies = cookies
                response.render()
```

Or any other nice plan? (or this issue was not correct?)
I don't know well about codes of django-debug-toolbar, so I didn't create PR yet.
Please ask and tell me anything.

items.title: debugsqlshell compatiblity with django-extensions' shell_plus
items.body:
[improvement]

Currently `debugsqlshell` management command is basically Django's built-in `shell` command + extra options that debug toolbar provides. 

I think it would be great if debug toolbar used `django-extensions`' `shell_plus` command instead of vanilla django shell **or** had another management command (like `debugsqlshell_plus`) that used shell plus.

It isn't really hard to implement in the first sight; just changing

```
from django.core.management.commands.shell import Command  # noqa
```

to
```
try:
    from django_extensions.managemen.commands.shell_plus import Command # noqa
except ImportError:
    # In case django extensions is not installed 
    from django.core.management.commands.shell import Command  # noqa
```

will do.


I think adding this feature is just a matter of your decision.

items.title: debug-toolbar doesn't work correctly with django-hosts
items.body: Today I discovered that django-debug-toolbar doesn't work correctly on subdomains with django-hosts library. I am adding the debug-toolbar urls also for the subdomain, but the problem is the url for the ajax request is created with a template tag like: {% url 'djdt:render_panel' %} and it doesn't contain the host parameter, so it defaults to www in my case, and that's forbidden because of access control. I'm not sure what's the correct way to resolve this problem, maybe creating a template tag for the url creation which could also take the current host into account, but that doesn't seem right to me.

items.title: Extreme slowdown when toolbar enabled
items.body: We are experiencing abnormal, extreme slowdown of pages loading when the debug toolbar is enabled. The below image shows 2 requests to the same page, once with the toolbar enabled and once with it disabled. The page load time increases from ~7 seconds to ~150. The database queries it does remains the same, it's purely python work that is different. I have collected profiles of each request (in this case the`change_view` method of the above admin) using django-silk: [profiles.zip](https://github.com/jazzband/django-debug-toolbar/files/1422198/profiles.zip) I'm no expert at this, from what I can gather, it looks like it's spending a huge amount of time in the `pprint.py` file, on the `_safe_repr` method (jump in the 4th column, being total passed time): Our environment is Python 2.7, Django 1.11.

items.title: Show django-debug-toolbar in admin pages

items.title: Directory traversal on template_origin variable
items.body:
We have enabled debug toolbar on our test environment of Django 1.10.17. After auditing the site we have found that template_origin variable is not correctly sanitized. I understand this is a Debug addon that probably isn't aimed for production environments, but I wanted only to report this just as an informative post. 
Maybe this is the intended behavior of this variable. If this is correct, sorry for this post!

Proof of concept:

http://FQDN/__debug__/template_source/?template=pages/home.html&template_origin=/etc/passwd

![screenshot from 2017-08-09 14-36-37](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7797734/29136999-50ddf02e-7d15-11e7-8f14-916671582187.png)


Affected file: 

panels/templates/views.py

Affected portion of code:

`def template_source(request):
    """
    Return the source of a template, syntax-highlighted by Pygments if
    it's available.
    """
    template_origin_name = request.GET.get('template_origin', None)
    if template_origin_name is None:
        return HttpResponseBadRequest('"template_origin" key is required')
    template_name = request.GET.get('template', template_origin_name)

    final_loaders = []
    loaders = Engine.get_default().template_loaders

    for loader in loaders:
        if loader is not None:
            # When the loader has loaders associated with it,
            # append those loaders to the list. This occurs with
            # django.template.loaders.cached.Loader
            if hasattr(loader, 'loaders'):
                final_loaders += loader.loaders
            else:
                final_loaders.append(loader)

    for loader in final_loaders:
        if Origin:  # django>=1.9
            origin = Origin(template_origin_name)
            try:
                source = loader.get_contents(origin)
                break
            except TemplateDoesNotExist:
                pass
        else:  # django<1.9
            try:
                source, _ = loader.load_template_source(template_name)
                break
            except TemplateDoesNotExist:
                pass
    else:
        source = "Template Does Not Exist: %s" % (template_origin_name,)

    try:
        from pygments import highlight
        from pygments.lexers import HtmlDjangoLexer
        from pygments.formatters import HtmlFormatter

        source = highlight(source, HtmlDjangoLexer(), HtmlFormatter())
        source = mark_safe(source)
        source.pygmentized = True
    except ImportError:
        pass
`
Regards,

items.title: SHOW_TOOLBAR_CALLBACK change in django-debug-toolbar 1.8 breaks existing code and it is not documented
items.body:
In django-debug-toolbar 1.7 and below, the `SHOW_TOOLBAR_CALLBACK` callback is used to check both whether a request  to  debug-toolbar views should be authorized and whether a request is ajax.

In django-debug-toolbar 1.8, the ajax check is moved into the middleware, and it raises a 404 if a request can not pass the SHOW_TOOLBAR_CALLBACK check.

So a callback written for django-debug-toolbar<=1.7 will broken debug-toolbar 1.8's ajax request. :-(

Debug-toolbar's own doc still indicates that the callback should check if the request is AJAX, it's confusing：

> The default checks are that DEBUG must be set to True, the IP of the request must be in INTERNAL_IPS, and the request must not be an AJAX request. 

Because those 404s do not have explicit error messages, it is even harder to find the root cause.

items.title: Incorrectly parse versions of some apps
items.body:
I saw that for `django-celery-beat` and `django-celery-results` it shows extra dots at the end of the version:
```
django_celery_beat	Django_Celery_Beat	1.0.1..
django_celery_results	Django_Celery_Results	1.0.1..
```

This is because both apps use custom `namedtuple`:
```
version_info_t = namedtuple('version_info_t', (
    'major', 'minor', 'micro', 'releaselevel', 'serial',
))
```

When `releaselevel` and `serial` are not set they are empty strings. This will lead to joining dots in the string representation.

I'm preparing a fix and will create a PR.

items.title: Global settings for access mixins
items.body:
In a project, we usually have a global way of handling accesses in views.
The problem with access current access mixins, we need to configure *raise_exception*, *redirect_unanthenticated_users* and other mixins settings in the view class.
If I'm not wrong, their is two way of having the same settings on all views:

  + create our own AccessMixins with those attribute set to our required values.
  + set those settings in each views.

In one of my project, I had a huge number of views I needed to re-configure access for.

I think we need to have some globals settings that should be set to configure access mixins default attribute values. For exemple:

```python
# file: settings.py

BRACES = {
    'access_raise_exception': True,
    'redirect_unauthenticated_users': True,
}
```

items.title: Missing sqlparse version on setup.py for older versions(<=1.4) of django-debug-toolbar
items.body:
Hi,

I'do like to point for the fact that sqlparse's version is missing on the requirements part of the setup.py of older versions of django-debug-toolbar(<=1.4) and it's causing trouble since the lastest versions of sqlparse(>=0.2) aren't compatible with it. Just think you should know.

items.title: Poor performance in Django 1.11 after template-based widget rendering
items.body: As reported in Django's Trac ticket [#27774](https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/27774), enabling the "Templates" panel on a page that does a lot of template-widget rendering ([#15667](https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/15667)) results in unacceptably slow page load. I'm not sure what an appropriate resolution might be. A possibility could be to have the debug toolbar ignore analysis for widget rendering.

items.body:
```

```

My settings are divided between production and local, which I think is the problem: 

```

try:

```

items.title: Debug toolbar table CSS classnames missing djdt prefix
items.body:
I had my own css class called `.timeline` and it conflicted with the SQL query timeline such that it overflowed the page. It took me quite a bit to find that the root cause was conflicting class names. Perhaps it should have a debug toolbar prefix like `.djdt-timeline`?

I noticed this is in place for some, but not all of the `th` classes. Adding it to `.query` and `.timeline` would probably be best for consistency.

```html
<tr>
    <th class="djdt-color"> </th>
    <th class="query" colspan="2">Query</th>
    <th class="timeline">Timeline</th>
    <th class="djdt-time">Time (ms)</th>
    <th class="djdt-actions">Action</th>
</tr>
```

items.title: Can't find static files or template contexts
items.body:
I recently upgraded to Django 1.10, and after enough tweaks to get my site to run again, I noticed `debug-toolbar` is not showing which static files are used:

![staticfiles-no-show](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3335984/21596688/15f763a4-d104-11e6-992e-30b064a9ca8d.png)

It lists the static file count, and of those files at least 5 are being used but `debug-toolbar` doesn't know about them.

Also, the template contexts are not showing. The context is being passed to the template for sure, otherwise my site would be broken and blank. Of all the template contexts, `debug-toolbar` only knows about one of them:

![template-context-no-show](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3335984/21596699/4db7331e-d104-11e6-82f9-cb88eff20ea5.png)

The one that shows, the `<unknown source>` template, is rendered with a regular `Context()` object. The rest are rendered with a `RequestContext()`. That's the only difference I can see. Let me know if you need more info on this one. I love using `django-debug-toolbar`, and I'd be glad to help fix this. I haven't had time to dig in to the source for `debg-toolbar` but I will if I need to.

Thanks,
-Chris

items.title: support params in sql panel that cannot be JSON encoded by default JSONEncoder
items.body:
If sql params are values that cannot be encoded by the built-in `json.JSONEncoder`, then the sql panel doesn't get the params and subsequently can't perform the query or `EXPLAIN` the query.

In my case, I often have params that are instance of `datetime.datetime`.

I currently use the following patch: https://github.com/zt-initech/django-debug-toolbar/commit/47e766434a81622d94432069257f7f4bc79e5dde

It is not very nice. I don't like using both JSON and pickle, and there are probably other problems.

How do you think this problem should be fixed?
For example, should params always be pickled?
Can you help me fix this patch to get it merged upstream?
